lg.l: In a Letter to ye 08. Songster────October──1729──────
To form a just & finish'd piece,
Take twenty Gods of Rome or Greece,
Whose Godships are in chief request,
& fit your present subject best.
& shoud it be your Hero's case
To have both Male & Female race,
your buiseness must be to provide
A score of Goddesses beside.Some call their Monarchs, sons of Saturn,
For which they bring a modern pattern;
because they might have heard of one,
who often long'd to eat his son:
but, this I think will not go down,
for here the Father kept his Crown.Why, then appoint him Son of Jove,
who met his mother in a Gove;
to this we freely shall consent,
well knowing what the Poets meant:
and in their sense, 'twixt me & you,
it may be literally true.next as the laws of song require,
he must be greater than his sire;
for, Iove as ev'ry school-boy knows,
was able Saturn to depose:
& sure, no Christian Poet breathing
shoud be more scroup'lous than a Heathen.
Or, if to blasphemy it tends
that's but a trifle among friends,your Hero now another Mars is,
makes mighty Armies turn their A──ses;
behold his glitt'ring faulchion mow
whole squadrons with a single blow:
while victory, with wings outspread,
flies like an Eagle o'er his head.
his milk white Steed upon its haunches,
or pawing into dead men's paunches;
as Overton has drawn his Sire,
still seen o'er many an Ale-house fire.
then from his Arm hoarse Thunder rolls,
as loud as fifty mustard bowls.
for, Thunder still his Arm supplies,
and lightning, always in his Eyes.
they both are cheap enough in consc'ence
& serve to echo rattling nonsence;
the rumbling words march fierce along
made trebbly dreadful in your song──
Sweet Poet, hir'd for birthday rimes
to sing of wars, chuse peaceful times;
what, 'tho for fifteen years & more,
Janus hath lock'd his Temple door,
'tho not a descenders coveredCoffey-House we read in
hath mention'd arms on this side Swedemasked
nor London-Journals, nor yẹ Post-men,
Though fond of warlike lies as most men;
Thou, still with Battles stuff thy head full,
for, must thy Hero not be dreadful?Dismissing Mars, it next must follow
your Conq'ror is become Apollo:
That he's Apollo, is as plain, as
That Robin Walpole is Mecenas;
but that he struts & that he squints 2]
you'd know him by Apollo's Prints.
Old Phoebus is but half as bright,
for yours can shine both Day & night;
the first, perhaps may once an Age
inspire you with poetick rage;
your Phoebus royal ev'ry day
not only can inspire, but pay:Then make this new Apollo sit
sole Patron, judge, & God of witt.

For Patrons never pay so well,
as when they scarce have learn'd to spell.next, call him Neptune with his Trident.
he rules the sea, you see him ride in't;
&, if provoak'd, he roundly ferks his
rebellious waves with rods like Xerxes.
he woud have seiz'd the spanish plate,
had not the Fleet gon out too late;
& in their very Ports besiege 'em,
but that he woud not disoblige 'em,
& made the Rascals pay him dearly,
for those affronts they give him yearly.'Tis not deny'd that when we write,
our ink is black, our paper white;
& when we scrawl our paper o'er,
we blacken what was white before;
I think this practice only fit
for dealers in satyrick witt:
but you, some white lead ink must get,
& write on paper black as jet;
your interest lyes to learn the knack
of whitening what before was black.Thus, your Encomiums to be strong,
must be apply'd directly wrong:
a Tyrant, for his mercy praise,
& crown a Royal dunce with Bays;
a squinting monkey load with charms;
& paint a Coward, fierce in arms:
is he to avarice inclin'd?
extoll him for his gen'rous mind:
&, when we starve for want of Corn,
come out with Amalthaea's horn.
for all experience this evinces
the only art of pleasing Princes;
for Princes love you shou'd descant,
on virtues which they know they want.
one compliment I had forgot,
but songsters must omit it not;
I freely grant the thought is old;
why then, your Hero must be told,
in him such virtues lie inherent,
to qualifie him, Gods vicegerent,
that with no title to inherit
He must have been a King by merit.
Yet be the fancy old or new
'tis partly false, & partly true.
& take it right, it means no more
than George & William claim'd before.shoud some obscure inferior Fellow
As Julius or the youth of Pella,
when all your list of Gods is out,
presume to shew his mortal snout,
& as a Deity intrude
because he had the World subdu'd,
Oh, let him not debase your thoughts
or name him, but to tell his faults.of Gods, J only quote the best;
but you may hook in all the rest.Now Birth-day Bard with joy proceed
to praise your Empress & her Breed.
first, of the first. to vouch your lies
bring all the Females of the skyes;
the Graces, & their mistress Venus
must venture down to entertain us:
with bended knees when they adore her
what Doudees they appear before her!
nor shall we think you talk at random,
for Venus, might be her great Grandam,
six thousand years has liv'd the Goddess,
your Heroine hardly fifty odd is.
besides, you songsters oft have shewn
that she hath Graces of her own;
three Graces by Lucina brought her,
just three, & ev'ry Grace a Daughter.
here many a King his heart & Crown
shall at their snowy feet lay down;
in Royal Robes they come by dozens
to Court their English German Cousins.
besides, a pair of Princly Baby's
that five years time will both be Hebe's.now see her seated on her Throne
with genuineorgen'ine lustre, all her own.Poor Cynthia never shone so bright
Her splendor is but borrow'd light;
& only with her Brother link'd
can shine, without him is extinct.
But Carolina shines the clearer
with neither Spouse nor Brother near her
and darts her beams o're both our Isles
though George is gon a thousand miles.
thus Berecynthia takes her place
attended by her Heav'nly race
& sees a son in ev'ry God
unaw'd by Jove's all shaking Nod.
now sing his little Highness Freddy,
who strutts like any King already;
with so much beauty, shew me any maid,
that coud resist this charming Ganymede.
where majesty with sweetness vies,
& like his Father, early wise.
then cut him out a world of work,
to conquer spain, & quell the Turk:
foretell his Empire crown'd with Bays,
& Golden times, & Halcyon days;
& swear, his line shall rule yẹ Nation
for ever──till the Conflagration.But, now it comes into my mind
we left a little Duke behind;
a Cupid in his face & seize,
& only wants, to want his Eyes.
make some provision for yẹ Yonker,
find him a Kingdom out to conquer;
prepare a Fleet to waft him o're,
make Gulliver his Commodore,
into whose pocket valiant Willy put,
will soon subdue yẹ Realm of Lilliput:A skilful Critick justly blames
Hard, tough, crank, gutt'ral, harsh, stiff names.
the sense can ne're be too jejune,
but smooth your words, to fit the tune.
Hannover may do well enough;
but, George, & Brunswick are too rough:
Hass-Darmstadt makes a rugged sound
& Guelp, the strongest ear will wound.
in vain are all attempts from Germany
to find out proper words for harmony:
& yet I must except the Rhine,
because it clinks to Caroline.
hail Queen of Britton, Queen of Rimes
be sung ten Hundred thousand times;
too happy were the Poets Crew,
if their own happiness they knew:
three syllables did never meet
so soft, so sliding, & so sweet:
nine other tuneful words like that
woud prove e'vn Homer's numbers flatt.
behold three beauteous Vowels stand
with Bride-Groom liquids, hand in hand;
in concord here for ever fix'd
no jarring Consonant betwixt.May Caroline continue long
for ever fair & young!────in song.
What? 'tho the Royal Carkass must
squeez'd in a Coffin turn to dust
those Elements her name compose
like Attoms, are exempt from blows.'Tho Carroline may fill your Gaps,
yet still, you must consult the Maps
find Rivers with harmonious names
Sabrina, Medway, & the Thames:
Brittania long will wear like steel;
But, Albion's Cliffs are out at heel;
&, patience can endure no more
to hear the Belgick Lyon roar.
give up the phrase of haughty Gual;
but, proud Iberia soundly maul:
restore the Ships by Philip taken,

but, much I fear, he's in decline:
& if you chance to come too late,
when he goes out, you share his fate,
& bear the new successors frown;
or, whom you once sung up, sing down,
reject with scorn that stupid notion
to praice your Hero for devotion;
nor entertain a thought so odd,
that Princes shoud believe in God;
but follow the securest rule,
and, turn it all to ridicule:
'tis grown the choicest witt at Court,
& gives the Maids of Honour, sport.
for, since they talk'd with Docṛ Clark
they now can venture in the dark;
that sound Divine the truth has spoke all
& pawn'd his word, Hell is not local.
this will not give them half the trouble,
of bargains sold, or meanings double.Supposing now your song is done,
To Min-heer Handel next you run;
who artfully will pare & prune
your words, to some Italian tune:
then print it in the largest letter
with Capitals, the more the better.
present it boldly on your knee,
